answers: cancers [accept any specific types of cancers]
parts: DNA is synthesized non-continuously on the lagging strand in the form of these short stretches of DNA named for a Japanese scientist. These stretches of DNA are later joined together by DNA ligase.
Pairs of these short oligonucleotides used in PCR should have melting temperatures within 5°C of each other and low complementarity to avoid forming their namesake “dimers.”

This group of diseases can be diagnosed by liquid biopsies that detect fragmented DNA known as circulating tumor DNA. These diseases are characterized by unchecked cell growth and may be treated with chemotherapy.

answers: Attack on Titan [or Shingeki no Kyojin]
parts: Name this TV show in which characters like Eren Jaeger (“YAY-gur”) and Levi Ackermann join the elite Survey Corps, which is part of Scout Regiment.

This anime distribution service was one of the first to legally release Attack on Titan in the US, despite previously being an illegal streaming site. In December 2020, Sony bought this website for over a billion dollars.
Attack on Titan was adapted from this medium. Many anime start off in the form of these Japanese graphic novels.

answers: swing [accept swing jazz; accept swing era; accept “King of Swing”]
parts: Give this term, which names an “era” of jazz characterized by danceable, syncopated rhythms. Bandleader Benny Goodman was rhymingly nicknamed the “King of” this term.
In Benny Goodman’s most famous concert, a swing song titled for this action opens with a drum solo by Gene Krupa. That song’s title refers to this action three times.

The singer says to “give it all that rhythm you got” in “It Don’t Mean a Thing (If It Ain’t Got That Swing),” a song written by this bandleader who collaborated with Billy Strayhorn on songs like "Take the A Train."

answers: love suicides [or shinjū; prompt on double suicides]
parts: Name these objects. In Japanese bunraku theatre, performers dressed in black manipulate these objects with wooden rods.
Many bunraku plays end with one of these events. The dramatist Chikamatsu Monzaemon wrote plays titled after "love" versions of these events at Sonezaki and Amijima.
The love suicides in Chikamatsu’s play take place in one of these locations. In As You Like It, Rosalind and Orlando meet in one of these locations named Arden.

answers: chemical weapons [or biological weapons; accept poison gases]
tsars of Russia [or emperors of Russia or monarchs of Russia; accept Alexander II or Alexander III; prompt on emperors or monarchs by asking "of which country?"]
parts: This type of weapon was utilized by members of the cult Aum Shinrikyo to target the Tokyo Metro. Use of these weapons, such as mustard gas, was banned by the 1925 Geneva Protocol after extensive use in World War I.

During a crash near Borki, one of these people allegedly saved his entire family by holding the roof of the train car up. Another one of these people was assassinated by a bomb detonated by members of the People’s Will.

In 1848, this railroad worker had a three-foot tamping iron driven up his skull. Despite this, he lived another 12 years and has become a case study of brain damage for psychologists and neuroscientists.

answers: philosopher kings [accept philosophers; prompt on kings]
divine right [or divine right of kings or divine right of monarchs; accept a deo lex, rege lex]
parts: In the metaphor of the "ship of state," Plato proposed that only these people are fit to lead. These people are said to be the only people with enough knowledge and openness to ideas to rule.

In the Middle Ages, this idea was used to legitimize many absolute monarchies. Under this idea, monarchs should not be bound by earthly restrictions because they derive their legitimacy from a higher power.

During this period, political philosophers such as John Locke promoted democratic ideals rather than the divine right of kings. This period is also called the Age of Reason for its emphasis on scientific rationalism.
Name these events, which began in the late 1800s as yearly exhibitions of agricultural products. They generally attract wider audiences than related “county”-level events.

“Farm shows” on Machinery Hill and hundreds of animal births at the Miracle of Birth Center can be seen at the state fair in this state, which takes place in a suburb of this state’s capital city of St. Paul.

At the Minnesota State Fair, the winner of the Princess Kay of the Milky Way contest gets a sculpture made of this medium. State fair sculptures of this medium initially became popular to promote refrigeration technology.

answers: the sun stone [or Piedra de Sol]
parts: Name this object, whose central depiction is believed to be the god Tonatiuh. One interpretation of this object's use is that it was a calendar, while another is that it was a testament to the political power of Montezuma II.
The sun stone was created in this city, which was legendarily founded at the site of an eagle perched on a cactus with a snake in its beak.
Tenochtitlan was the capital of this empire, which ruled Mesoamerica until the arrival of the Spanish.

answers: Washington, DC [accept DC or District of Columbia]
parts: Name this field of study that analyzes music through its cultural and social contexts, drawing heavily from anthropological methods.

The Folkways label, which released The Anthology of American Folk Music, now operates as part of the Smithsonian, a museum based in this city. The National Folklife Festival takes place on the National Mall in this city.
In ethnomusicology, recording done outside a recording studio is given this name, instead meeting artists where they are. A type of "work" given this name is an analogous concept in anthropology.

answers: Gothic fiction [or Gothic literature; do not accept or prompt on "Southern Gothic"]
parts: Name this author of “The Company of Wolves” and “The Tiger’s Bride.” This author’s feminist adaptations of fairy tales are collected in The Bloody Chamber.

“The Tiger’s Bride” is adapted from this fairy tale, which ends with the transformation of the title hideous creature into a handsome prince. Disney named the title princess "Belle" for their 1991 animated version.

Angela Carter's The Bloody Chamber belongs to this literary genre characterized by elements of horror, romance, and the supernatural. Another work in this genre is Horace Walpole’s The Castle of Otranto.

answers: Elijah [or Elias; or Eliyahu; or Illyas; do not accept or prompt on “Elisha”]
John the Baptist [or Yahya; or Yochanon]
parts: Name this prophet who some onlookers believe will rescue Jesus during his crucifixion. In Second Kings, this man is taken up to Heaven in a chariot of fire.
Elijah appears alongside Moses during this biblical event, in which Peter, James, and John witnessed Jesus shining radiantly.

During the Transfiguration, Jesus tells the disciples that Elijah had already come, which the disciples take to refer to this man. This man is called the “voice calling in the wilderness” and baptized Jesus in the Jordan River.

answers: electrical resistance [prompt on R; do not accept “resistivity”]
parts: Name this quantity, measured in ohms, that is equal to voltage divided by current.

The total resistance of resistors with this configuration equals the reciprocal of the sum of the reciprocals of the resistances. The total capacitance of capacitors in this configuration equals the sum of the capacitances.

If the resistances of three resistors are already known, then the resistance of a fourth can be found by arranging the four resistors into two legs bridged by a galvanometer in this diamond-shaped circuit configuration.

answers: Serenade No. 13 for Strings in G Major, Eine kleine Nachtmusik, K. 525 [accept any underlined portion; accept but DO NOT REVEAL A Little Night Music or A Little Serenade]
parts: Name this chamber work by Mozart, often performed by string orchestras. Its first theme is an example of a Mannheim rocket.
Eine kleine Nachtmusik is a serenade, which was typically performed at this general time of day.
Another genre of music evocative of night is this typically single-movement form developed by John Field. Chopin wrote 21 of these solo piano works with cantabile melodies.

Name this country that in March 2021 held its fourth national election in two years. Its governments are often formed of coalitions of smaller political parties like Yesh Atid and United Torah Judaism.
This leader of the Likud Party and current Prime Minister of Israel was indicted in November 2019 for bribery and fraud. He touted his close relationship with Donald Trump in recent elections.

In August 2020, this country agreed to normalize relations with Israel as part of a US-brokered deal dubbed the “Abraham Accords.” Bahrain, Sudan, and Morocco later followed this country in recognizing Israel.
Name these laws passed in many Northern states to counteract the effects of the Fugitive Slave Acts of 1793 and 1850. They guaranteed a jury trial to runaway slaves.
This 1857 Supreme Court decision ruled the Missouri Compromise unconstitutional and claimed that African Americans could not be American citizens.
This man served as Chief Justice for the Dred Scott decision. His initial nomination to the Supreme Court was defeated, but he was renominated once the Democrats had a larger share of the Senate.
Name this author who described Holden Caulfield’s journey through New York City in The Catcher in the Rye.
In The Catcher in the Rye, Holden uses this word to describe characters acting superficially to influence how others think of them. Holden calls Sally Hayes the queen of those people.
Holden relates that Mr. Antolini told Holden's brother D.B. not to go to this place, but that D.B. went anyway. Holden reiterates his dislike of this place throughout The Catcher in the Rye.
Name this quantity. Asymmetries in this quantity can be reduced by signaling, where the advantaged party increases this quantity in the disadvantaged party.
When individuals have imperfect information in these situations, they must consider many possible opponent actions. These situations name a field of economic theory that analyzes strategy.
This term describes a game state where no player can act unilaterally to improve their position. It is named after a Princeton mathematician who won the 1994 Nobel Prize in Economics.

answers: stop motion [accept claymation; prompt on animation]
parts: Name this character, whose mind can be accessed from the abnormally low-ceilinged 7th-and-a-half floor of the Mertin-Flemmer building.

Being John Malkovich was the first film for the screenwriter Charlie Kaufman, who directed a film titled for "Synecdoche, [this state]". In a 1933 film, planes fire at King Kong perched atop a landmark in this state.
Kaufman later directed Anomalisa, a film using this technique. This technique involves physically moving objects between film frames, and was used in Coraline and the Wallace and Gromit series.

answers: crossing the ocean [accept crossing the Pacific or sailing the Pacific; accept sailing to Polynesia]
parts: Manco Capac legendarily built a temple to the sun and founded the city of Cuzco where a golden one of these objects sank into the ground. Sun Wukong wields one of these objects that he can shrink at will.
Cuzco became the capital of this Andean empire that worshipped the sun disc Inti. This empire’s rulers were known as Sapa and thought to be descendants of the sun.
Viracocha, the Incan creator deity, died after performing this action. The story of Viracocha inspired Thor Heyerdahl to perform this action aboard the Kon-Tiki.

answers: partition coefficient [or distribution coefficient; prompt on P or D]
parts: Name this quantity, the ratio of a compound’s solubility in two immiscible liquids. This quantity in octanol and water is used as an indicator of a compound’s lipophilicity and hydrophilicity.
Immiscible liquids do not mix with each other but can form this type of mixture. Milk is an example of this type of colloid, which has two liquid phases.

Emulsions are prone to form in one type of this piece of lab equipment used in liquid-liquid extractions. The Büchner type of this object is used in filtration, and this object has a wide top opening and narrow bottom opening.
Name this empire whose heir Franz Ferdinand was assassinated in Sarajevo in 1914. This dual monarchy had two capitals at Vienna and Budapest.
This Austrian emperor created the Dual Monarchy with Hungary and reigned for over 60 years. Franz Ferdinand was the nephew and heir of this ruler until his assassination.

In the Hungarian portion of Austria-Hungary, the government engaged in this process of cultural assimilation of non-Hungarians. Members of other ethnic groups were forced to change their names under this process.
IEEE 802.3 governs this technology that transmits data in frames of at least 64 octets, often with twisted pair cables.
IEEE 802.11 sets the standards for this technology. A flaw in this technology’s WEP encryption led to the development of WPA and later WPA-2 and WPA-3.
The first iteration of this technology was governed by the IEEE 802.15.1 standard. Wireless speakers and headsets are "paired" to various media devices using this colorfully-named technology.

Name this poem whose title speaker vows to drink “life to the lees.” This poem by Alfred, Lord Tennyson closes with the speaker claiming he has the strength “to strive, to seek, to find, and not to yield.”
Ulysses is the Latin variant of the name of this Greek hero, who returns to Ithaca after the Trojan War in an epic poem by Homer.

Another Tennyson poem adapted from the Odyssey is titled for these people. These mild-mannered people consumed their namesake narcotic fruit, which would cause a traveler to forget home and sleep all day.

answers: Paris Street; Rainy Day [or Rue de Paris, temps de pluie]
luncheons [or Luncheon of the Boating Party]
parts: Name this painting that depicts fashionably-dressed men and women walking about the title location, all with blue-gray umbrellas. It is the best-known painting of Gustave Caillebotte (“kye-BUTT”).
Rather than umbrellas, many people in this French Pointillist artist's A Sunday Afternoon on the Island of La Grande Jatte are holding parasols to protect them from the sun.
Pierre-Auguste Renoir also depicted a Woman with a Parasol, this time in a garden. More famously, Renoir depicted Caillebotte and others attending one of these events on a boat.
